awd_titl_txt: HSI Pilot Project: Promoting Virtual Experiential Learning to Support Part-time and Nontraditional Students
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to create virtual experiential learning opportunities that are specifically aimed at part-time and non-traditional students attending Palo Alto College, an Hispanic-serving community college in the greater San Antonio area. The project team is focusing on these particular students for several reasons. Internships and undergraduate research opportunities are essential for students to gain real-world experience and improve their competitiveness upon entering the STEM workforce, while also increasing academic engagement. However, non-traditional and part time students often encounter significant challenges when they are pursuing such co-curricular experiences. Moreover, career services that assist in preparing students for internships are typically optimized to support traditional full-time students. This project will pilot the provision of quality career preparation using a virtual format to improve both access to, and the quality of, professional experiences for part-time and non-traditional student populations.

A key driver of the project's investigators is to capitalize on employers’ recent adoption of remote working and virtual internships as part of their response to COVID-19. Remote and virtual internships may be more accessible to part-time and non-traditional students that may be unable to make a daily commute to an office building or lab. The project will create partnerships with STEM employers and 4-year universities to establish virtual internships and undergraduate research opportunities. New Career Support Services for part-time and non-traditional students will include streaming presentations from industry speakers, access to peer mentors/embedded tutors, and online platforms for building essential professional skills. Three goals guide the project. First is to increase participation in internships and undergraduate research. Second is to improve access to professional networking and high-engagement activities. Third is to increase the availability of virtual mentoring/tutoring for part-time and non-traditional students. Research from this project will generate new knowledge about effective approaches that will increase retention and graduation rates of undergraduate students pursuing degrees in STEM fields at HSIs and two-year colleges. Project outcomes will be disseminated regionally, statewide, and nationally, through conferences, submissions to peer-reviewed journals, and sharing with existing NSF-HSI projects. The HSI Program aims to enhance undergraduate STEM education, broaden participation in STEM, and build capacity at HSIs. Achieving these aims, given the diverse nature and context of the HSIs, requires innovative approaches that incentivize institutional and community transformation and promote fundamental research (i) on engaged student learning, (ii) about what it takes to diversify and increase participation in STEM effectively, and (iii) that improves our understanding of how to build institutional capacity at HSIs.  Projects supported by the HSI Program will also draw from these approaches to generate new knowledge on how to achieve these aims.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, Palo Alto College was awarded The HSI Pilot Project, titled "Promoting Virtual Experiential Learning to Support Part-time and Nontraditional Students," aimed to support part-time and nontraditional Hispanic students in STEM fields by promoting virtual experiential learning opportunities. This initiative sought to address barriers to participation, such as limited time and access, by utilizing technology to create flexible and accessible programs. The project’s intellectual merit and broader impacts are evident in the achievement of key objectives that improved student engagement, career readiness, and mentoring opportunities.

Major Activities and Accomplishments

The project successfully partnered with industry leaders and four-year universities, offering internships and undergraduate research opportunities to students. Specifically, students had the chance to intern with a local ISD in San Antonio, TX, gaining valuable work experience in STEM-related fields. These opportunities were designed to address the needs of part-time and non-traditional students, who often face challenges with traditional in-person programs/internships.

To increase participation, the project utilized technology to facilitate virtual and on-campus meetings, ensuring that students could engage in STEM organizations regardless of their schedules. The soft skills programming, which is essential for career development, was delivered both in person and through the Canvas platform, allowing for flexibility in learning.

Career development was further supported by hosting career speakers in the STEM center, which were available both in person and online, allowing students to interact with professionals from the field. Virtual career fairs and networking events also enabled students to connect with potential employers in a blended format, making these opportunities accessible to a broader audience.

Additionally, the project provided peer mentors and embedded tutors in STEM courses. These mentors met bi-monthly with students in a blended format to provide guidance and support, further enriching the learning experience. Students were also able to interact with industry mentors via remote technology, providing a platform for feedback and professional development.

Specific Objectives and Achievements

The project aimed to meet four main objectives:

Establish an online soft skills development program: This objective was successfully achieved by integrating the career readiness soft skills program into a Canvas course. This approach enabled part-time students to engage in the program at their own pace, contributing to increased participation.

Increase engagement in STEM-related career development activities: Although this objective was partially achieved, the project faced challenges in offering virtual internships, as students expressed a preference for in-person internships. Despite this, the project succeeded in providing a range of virtual and blended activities that encouraged engagement in career development.

Increase participation in professional networking and high-engagement activities: This objective was fully achieved through the Career Launch program, where students had the opportunity to participate in internships and interact with employers, strengthening their professional networks.

Increase virtual mentoring/tutoring: This objective was successfully accomplished, as students were able to arrange tutoring sessions via Zoom, facilitating continued academic support and mentorship.

Significant Results and Key Outcomes

The soft skills curriculum was delivered to 30 students, with seven students completing all coursework associated with the Career Readiness program. Of these students, three were placed into compensated internships, gaining valuable work experience. Students reported that participation in the program boosted their confidence, networking abilities, and understanding of professional expectations.

Furthermore, the integration of technology allowed for the development of a flexible, accessible learning environment that addressed the unique needs of part-time and nontraditional students. Students expressed how the program not only improved their technical skills but also prepared them for real-world challenges in their careers.

Lessons Learned and Areas for Improvement

While the project achieved many of its goals, there were areas for improvement. One key lesson was the importance of integrating the program directly into instructors’ courses, which would ensure that all students, particularly those in the control group, engage with the content. Additionally, providing stipends to instructors who facilitate this integration could incentivize their involvement and increase program success.

Another area for improvement was the lack of control group feedback, which would have provided valuable insights into the effectiveness of the program. Including a control group and requiring them to complete surveys about their current knowledge of networking and internship experience would allow for a more comprehensive evaluation of the program’s impact.

In conclusion, the HSI Pilot Project successfully met many of its objectives, enhancing the academic and professional development of part-time and nontraditional Hispanic STEM students. The project demonstrated the potential of virtual experiential learning to create flexible, accessible opportunities for students while also fostering a supportive environment for career growth. Moving forward, the integration of these programs into academic curricula and the inclusion of additional evaluative measures would further strengthen the impact of such initiatives.
